fields.headline: News in brief
fields.bodyText: Jammie Dodgers firm sold in £200m deal Burton's Foods, makers of Jammie Dodgers, Wagon Wheels and Maryland Cookies, is changing hands in a deal understood to value the business at £200m. The company, Britain's second largest biscuits manufacturer, has been acquired by the private equity firm Duke Street Capital whose portfolio of investments includes the Focus DIY chain and Accantia, the Simple soaps producer. Burton's employs 3,000 people on five sites in the UK. Founded in the 1930s it became part of Associated British Foods in 1949 before being sold to Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst seven years ago. Geoff Gibbs House prices still rising as spring pick-up kicks in UK house prices rose in March by the biggest monthly amount since November, according to the latest survey from property website Rightmove. As the usual spring pick-up kicked in, asking prices over the past month rose 1.5% to an average £228,183. Year-on-year, prices were up 12.2% in March, slightly up on February's 11.5%. Rightmove's commercial director Miles Shipside said fears of more interest rate rises were being overshadowed by the effect of supply shortages. "Moderating house price growth in the long term is dependent on building more homes where people want to live," he said. Katie Allen Mothercare has eye on toddler toy stores ELC Mothercare yesterday confirmed talks over acquiring Chelsea Stores' Early Learning Centre stores for £85m, a tie-up that could add to its business locations and allow it to branch into toys and books. Under its chief executive, Ben Gordon, Mothercare has seen a turnaround with improved stores and ranges, reporting pre-tax profits for its last fiscal year of £24.2m, a rise of more than 50% on a year earlier. It has about 230 stores in the UK and 300 or so franchised shops overseas. ELC was bought three years ago for £62m from 3i, by a consortium fronted by the bookshop founder Tim Waterstone. Katie Allen
